X Margrethe Vestager not afraid to take on Europeâ€™s taxing issues EU competition commissioner is adamant Apple tax ruling is not political issue Fri, Oct 21, 2016, 06:00 Suzanne Lynch European Correspondent European Union competition commissioner Margrethe Vestager: â€œWe look at state aid from any possible angle to see if tools are being used that shouldnâ€™t be use to give a selective advantage.â€ Photograph: Eric Vidal/Reuters Â  Â  Â  Â  There are not many European Union commissioners who can boast of high popularity ratings. But in the two years since her appointment as Europeâ€™s competition chief Margrethe Vestager has succeeded in pulling off the unimaginable: becoming a much-loved Brussels â€œEurocratâ€. During a debate on the Apple judgment in the European Parliament last month, MEPs fell over themselves to applaud the Danish commissioner on her record ruling against Ireland. â€œI want to clone you,â€ said Belgian MEP Philippe Lamberts. Others complimented her on her â€œbraveryâ€ and â€œcourageâ€ in taking on Ireland and Apple. Long-time tax campaigner Sven Giegold said she â€œdeserved a medalâ€. The love-bombing was unrelentless, leaving Irish MEPs SeÃ¡n Kelly and Brian Hayes to put forward the case valiantly for Ireland. The exercise ultimately proved fruitless as MEPs from across the continent appeared to unleash decades of pent-up frustration at Irelandâ€™s corporate tax policy. Seven weeks after the Apple judgment, the Danish commissioner and former deputy prime minister sits in her 10th floor office in the European Commissionâ€™s headquarters in Brussels. Confident and smiling, wearing killer heels and a leather skirt, she looks every inch the fictional politician she is believed to have inspired in the hit Danish political drama Borgen. The room itself is a nod to Scandinavian minimalism: all clean lines and monochrome surfaces. A friendly aide brings in two trendy handle-less coffee cups. The office is somewhere between an Ikea catalogue and a manifestation of â€œhyggeâ€, the new Danish lifestyle craze that translates roughly as â€œcosinessâ€ and is taking the design world by storm. That Margrethe Vestager has managed to bring her own idiosyncratic style to the drab world of EU bureaucratic decor is not surprising. This is a woman who is very much putting her stamp on things. Though she inherited many of the most high-profile anti-trust cases from her predecessor JoaquÃ­n Almunia, Vestager has taken up the mantle and gone further than many had expected. ADVERTISEMENT Apple judgment Quite apart from the Apple judgment, Vestagerâ€™s in-tray is full. There are three open cases against Google; there are also suggestions she may open a fourth front over â€œscrapingâ€, the process of copying content from websites without payment, while an assessment of the Microsoft-LinkedIn merger awaits. Russian energy giant Gazprom has also been in the commissionerâ€™s sights, while the 800 or so staff employed by the EUâ€™s competition directorate-general located a kilometre down the road in Merode are busy sifting through thousands of tax rulings, including a trawl of documents unveiled by the Luxembourg Leaks scandal. But the last few months have been dominated by the Apple case. The order by the European Commission that Ireland collect up to â‚¬13 billion in unpaid taxes broke new ground. Though the EUâ€™s anti-trust division had previously dabbled in state aid, the record for a state aid case had been â‚¬1.3 billion in 2014. Competition experts will be watching eagerly how this plays out in the courts. With the Government expected to refer the case to the European Court of Justice by early November, is she confident that the commission will win its case? â€œWe knew this was coming. We knew there would be an appeal so we are very prepared,â€ she says. â€œItâ€™s important that we get to set out our reasons, our argument. All that is set out in the full judgment, of course, but itâ€™s a key part of the EU competition procedure.â€ The finding by the commission that Apple benefitted from â‚¬13 billion in illegal tax aid from Ireland has spooked the Government here, raising serious questions about Irelandâ€™s economic model of attracting foreign direct investment. Next week the European Commissionâ€™s commissioner responsible for taxation, Pierre Moscovici, is expected to come forward with a revised proposal for a common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB). French prime minister Manuel Valls said last week he wanted to move towards a common corporate tax rate in Europe. Vestager insists the Apple decision was rooted in state aid and not tax concerns. â€œWe do not do tax, we do state aid,â€ she says. â€œWe look at state aid through all the tools you can use to give state aid, be it, in this issue, as a tax ruling, be it a cheap piece of land as in one of the Spanish football cases, maybe a favourable loan as in the French EDF case, or as cash . . . we look at state aid from any possible angle to see if tools are being used that shouldnâ€™t be use to give a selective advantage.â€ Political concerns However, as critics of the Apple decision have been quick to point out, how can the EUâ€™s competition division claim not to be motivated by political concerns when European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker has vowed to make his commission the most political European Commission in history? Itâ€™s an issue that raises broader questions about whether the EUâ€™s competition division â€“ by far the most powerful arm of the European Commission with semi-judicial powers â€“ should come under the umbrella of the commission or should instead be a stand-alone institution. â€œI donâ€™t think our work is political,â€ says Vestager in response. â€œWe have safeguards so we can take independent decisions. It is true that our decisions are fact-based, based on the evidence of the case, our case law, our case practice. If you are looking for politics, it is in a much deeper sense. â€œOf course, our founding fathers put political values into the EU treaty. Itâ€™s not a neutral document. They made choices, and they said we want a level playing field, we want equal treatment, and we want us all to have a fair chance in the market . . . These values I and my team are obliged to protect.â€ ADVERTISEMENT Others point out that there is a contradiction at the heart of the Apple ruling which, on the one hand, ordered Ireland to recoup unpaid taxes by the US company, while on the other said that other countries could be entitled to some of the spoils. Vestager disputes that there is any problem here. â€œThese are two separate issues. The decision itself is about how Apple organised itself and how Irish tax legislation sits with tax rulings. In that instance, we found that the Irish should recover unpaid taxes. As a side issue, there is a question about how Apple organised itself to distribute its hardware to the African, Middle East, Indian market, etc.â€ She says that, while typically value is not created at these â€œselling pointsâ€ as contractually people are still buying their phone from Cork, Ireland, â€œsometimes the distributional arrangements evolve into something that actually does create value on siteâ€. She says it may now be relevant for national authorities to consider if this distribution arrangement has changed and make a claim to some of the money, though the European Commission has no role in this. â€œThe way tax is organised in Europe, it is for all intents and purposes, a national competence, apart from recent legislation on automatic exchange of information, etc. Tax authorities donâ€™t operate on a European level,â€ Vestager says. Legal challenge However, while the intricacies of competition law will be combed through in the forthcoming legal challenge, there are also questions about the way the commission handled the communication of the ruling. While Irish officials and EU commissioner Phil Hogan were told of the â‚¬13 billion figure on the morning of the announcement on August 30th, it is understood that the Government and Minister for Finance Michael Noonan were informed that the figure would be â€œbillionsâ€ towards the end of the previous week. â€œItâ€™s always very difficult to say, well, what you should exchange. Of course, weâ€™d been working with the Irish Government, because itâ€™s always the government that you deal with as the counterpart,â€ she says. â€œWe have treated it as we have every other case and have been working with the Government in giving the warnings as we have done in every other case. Of course, itâ€™s up to everyone to consider how they will prepare themselves when they know something is coming, just as well as we do.â€ In terms of future cases, Vestager does not rule out further investigations into Irelandâ€™s tax arrangements with companies. â€œI cannot say that there wonâ€™t be more cases, but I cannot say that there will be more cases. I stay neutral until we figure out there is something we really have to look into,â€ she says. â€œWe have a sample of 1,000 tax rulings overall. The majority of them are the rulings from â€˜Lux Leaksâ€™, but we have 10, 12 tax rulings from all the member states who do tax rulings. Weâ€™ve been going through these and what weâ€™ve found is that a number of them are absolutely fine.â€ Because Ireland issues far fewer tax agreements than the other 22 member states which issue tax rulings â€“ Germany, for example, issues tens of thousands of tax rulings â€“ Irish authorities are understood to have submitted virtually all Irelandâ€™s tax letters which number a few hundred. Further, these were submitted before the European Commission extended its request for information to all EU member states in December 2014. Vestager plays down any suggestion that Ireland can therefore be expected to be at the front of the queue for forthcoming judgments. â€œThatâ€™s not the way we workâ€ she said. ADVERTISEMENT Tense exchanges While the commission is still trawling through the cache of documents uncovered by the Luxembourg Leaks scandal, does it present Vestager with a difficulty that her boss, Jean-Claude Juncker, was prime minister of Luxembourg when most of these tax deals were struck? â€œI donâ€™t feel it like that,â€ she says. â€œJuncker was very clear with me, from the very early days to say, â€˜You have completely free hands to do what you believe is the right thing to doâ€™ and that is how weâ€™re working.â€ While the Apple ruling has strained relations between Dublin and Brussels, it has also compounded tensions between Brussels and Washington amid accusations that Europe is unfairly targeting US companies. When US treasury secretary Jack Lew visited Vestager in July, officials reported that the Danish commissioner gave him short shrift during tense exchanges. Vestager declines to comment on the meeting, but she does expand on the transatlantic relationship . Following her trip to Washington last month in the wake of the Apple judgment, she tweeted as she sat on the runway that visiting the United States â€œmakes me feel more European than everâ€, adding that she was looking forward to going back home. For countries such as Ireland, which in many ways see themselves closer to Boston than Berlin, is this not a concern? â€œI really did see the differences. There is a different tradition of competition policy in Europe and America. From the beginning, the European Union chose to put a ban on taxpayersâ€™ money being put into supporting businesses selectively. On the contrary, it seems to be absolutely normal for businesses in the US to directly negotiate how much taxes they are going to pay with the state where they place their business. Itâ€™s a discussion about two very different ways of doing things,â€ she says. As for the future of transatlantic relations, there are no plans for further visits to the US until the spring, she says. The imminent change in the US administration means that diplomatic engagement is likely to be minimal from Washingtonâ€™s end. Major concern While she insists on the independence of the EUâ€™s competition arm, Vestager believes taxation has become a major public concern across the world, and she supports, though is not directly involved with, her colleague Pierre Moscoviciâ€™s CCCTB proposal. â€œI remember when Denmark held the presidency of the council in 2012 and I was at the table as finance minister, we were trying to secure agreement on automatic exchange of information on a wider range of personal income, with very little luck I have to say. A few years later, it passed,â€ she says. She believes there has been a sea change in public perceptions around tax. â€œTo a large degree, it has come from the financial and sovereign debt crisis. People have seen their governments do unthinkable things to get in control of their spending . They have seen public salaries, benefits, pensions go down, taxes go up. They feel that they all contribute to make ends meet, and then they see that not all businesses contribute. It is unfair,â€ she says. As for her own future, Vestagerâ€™s huge public profile, which was enhanced by hundreds of media appearances and interviews during the Apple controversy, has sparked speculation in Brussels that she could be lining up for a senior international position when her term as commissioner ends in 2019. Asked whether she would return to Danish politics or consider going further afield, she remains coy. â€œI donâ€™t envision my future. I have never really planned because, to me, having a plan is like when a horse wears blinkers. If you put them on, you donâ€™t see whatâ€™s happening out there, but sometimes the best things are happening out of the corner of your eye,â€ she says. ADVERTISEMENT For her, itâ€™s not about â€œclimbing the ladder, or thinking of the next phaseâ€. She adds with a smile: â€œI work from the hypothesis that I have one try at this life so better do something that you find worthwhile.â€ Watch this space. CV: Margrethe Vestager Job: European Commissioner for Competition Age: 48 Family: Married with three daughters Hobbies: Knitting, watching films Something we might expect: An economics graduate, Vestager was made education minister in Denmark at the age of 29 and served as economy minister and deputy prime minister under prime minister Helle Thorning-Schmidt Something that might surprise you: Despite her recent clash with Apple, the Danish commissioner is an avid iPad user Â  Â  Â  Topics: Apple tax Brian Hayes Helle Thorning Schmidt Jack Lew Jean Claude Juncker Joaquin Almunia Manuel Valls Margrethe Vestager Michael Noonan Phil Hogan Philippe Lamberts Pierre Moscovici Sean Kelly Sven Gielgold European Commission Apple Gazprom Google Read More European Commission refuses to comment on Noonan claims EU tax harmonisation: an issue that wonâ€™t go away Apple expects to offset â‚¬13bn Irish tax bill by paying less in US Cantillon: Appleâ€™s Irish tax woes the least of its problems No state-aid inquiries expected after Apple case, says Kenny Commission may examine 300 more Irish tax rulings Revenue chairman disputes Apple claims of 2% tax deal EU not investigating Googleâ€™s European tax deals â€“ Vestager â€˜Irish Timesâ€™ poll: Majority support appeal of Apple ruling Subscribe. The revelation comes in a federal lawsuit filed by Apple against a New Jersey company on Monday over what Apple says are counterfeit products that were sold on Amazon. In the lawsuit, Apple says Mobile Star imprinted Apple logos on cables and chargers that "pose a significant risk of overheating, fire, and electrical shock." It says the chargers and cables were being sold on Amazon as genuine Apple products. Apple says it purchased the products on Amazon and later told the online retailer that they were fake. Amazon then identified Mobile Star as the source. Amazon isn't named in the suit, but said in a statement that it has "zero tolerance" for counterfeiters on its site and that it pursues "wrongdoers" aggressively. Mobile Star didn't return a voicemail seeking comment. Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. RecomN - Local Services|Â About Us|Â E-Paper|Â Search|Â MOBILE KLIK UNTUK PROJEKMMO ç‚¹å‡»Mä¸­æ–‡ç½‘ Facebook Twitter RSS Last updated Tuesday, November 15, 2016 8:20 am GMT+8 Kuala Lumpur Â°C, MMOTV News Malaysia World Money Life Showbiz Opinion Sports Eat/Drink Travel Read Tech/Gadgets Drive Gallery Tech/Gadgets Struggling Chinese unicorn Xiaomi bets on smart rice cookers Friday October 21, 2016 12:51 PM GMT+8 ICYMI The Edit: Frida Kahlo painting, unseen for 60 years, surfaces for sale Rooney out of Spain game, Henderson to captain England The Edit: Supermoon wows stargazers tonight Sweden starts grilling of Assange at Ecuador embassy Advertisement More stories Â Â  Â Â  Â Â  Â Â  Â Â  Tools Increase Text Decrease Text Reset Text Print Article The company was once Chinaâ€™s top smartphone seller and for a time the worldâ€™s largest unicorn after Uber. But its dominance has proved fleeting because consumers have moved upmarket. â€• Reuters picBEIJING, Oct 21 â€” On a recent afternoon in northern Beijing, Chinese 20-somethings lean over a long blond-wood table in a retail store, examining colourful smartphones and fitness bands. The white walls and spare space recall an Apple Store, but on display is a wider, and more curious, range of products: â€œsmartâ€ rice-cookers, hoverboards, robot vacuum cleaners, bathroom scales and air purifiers. A tall salesman in a bright blue T-shirt says they are planning to soon cordon off an area to demo Xiaomi drones. The brightly lit store is one of 36 locations across Greater China operated by Xiaomi Corp, a Beijing-based smartphone-maker that has been frequently touted as the â€œApple of China.â€ But Xiaomi has a very different strategy: Instead of meticulously designing products in-house, guided by the technical and aesthetic vision of a Steve Jobs-like figure, Xiaomi is investing in dozens of Chinese hardware startups, branding the devices with the Xiaomi label, and selling them in stores and through its website. The gadgets can be operated from a Xiaomi smartphone â€” a classic Internet of Things play â€” and are typically priced near the low range of competing products. The rice cooker costs about US$150 (RM600), more expensive than traditional electronic cookers, but far below top-end products from Philips and Toshiba, which can run to US$450. The Mi Band 2 fitness-tracker costs US$22, about a fifth the price of Fitbit Alta. The strategy is familiar enough: Hook customers on an operating system â€” MIUI, a heavily customised version of Androidâ€“so theyâ€™ll stay loyal to the brand and keep buying more products. Liu De, who runs Xiaomiâ€™s new ecosystems products division, says the business will pull in 10 billion yuan this year â€” splitting profits with Xiaomiâ€™s hardware partners â€” and double that in 2017. He accepts that this is a â€œvery ambitious goal.â€ Xiaomi badly needs a second act. A couple of years ago, the company was Chinaâ€™s top smartphone seller and for a time the worldâ€™s largest unicorn after Uber. But its dominance has proved fleeting because consumers have moved upmarket. â€œThey want to get more premium phones and are willing to pay more,â€ says Jessie Ding, a China market analyst at Canalys. â€œHowever, Xiaomiâ€™s specs have not changed much over past two years.â€ Meanwhile, competition from domestic phone makers has intensified, knocking Xiaomi into fourth place. The company is trying to claw its way back. Led by Vice President of Global Operations Hugo Barra, Xiaomi is pushing into other developing markets. India is a particular focus because, like China five years ago, most consumers want value for money, says Tarun Pathak, a market analyst at Counterpoint Research. But he says it wonâ€™t be long before Indians, too, will want better phones. Later this month, Xiaomi will launch a premium smartphone with a screen that curves around the side like a Samsung Edge, according to people familiar with the plan. A smart watch is also expected to debut later this year. If the new phone doesnâ€™t jumpstart sales, Xiaomiâ€™s growth prospects may rest with Liu and his ecosystems division. To date, Liu says his team has invested in more than 60 startups, largely founded in the last three years, and remains a minority shareholder in most of them. Xiaomi also offers input on product design and marketing. â€œWe target big markets, big demands,â€ he says, explaining that the aim is to maintain a steady pace of innovation so consumers will want to replace or upgrade every few years. Chief among the startups is Huami, the fitness band maker, which was founded in 2014 by serial entrepreneur Wang Huang. It has raised money from Sequoia, Morningside Venture and Banyan Capital. Headquartered in Beijing, the company also has a Silicon Valley engineering office and more than 300 employees. In the US, it has launched the pricier Amazfit fitness tracker. It resembles a wristwatch adorned with a jade-pendant-like sensor â€” evoking traditional Chinese jade jewellery â€” while tracking steps and calculating calories burned. Huami declined to comment. Most of the products in the Xiaomi ecosystem have a similar modern aesthetic, with simple colours, rounded edges and minimally fussy dials or buttons. Part of the sales strategy involves persuading consumers to buy things they donâ€™t know they need. Unveiling the smart rice-cooker this spring in Beijing, Liu De displayed a chart with two coloured lines indicating, respectively, optimal stickiness-sweetness and optimal texture-colour; where they cross, he explained, is perfect rice. Customers using Xiaomiâ€™s cooker can scan the bar code on rice packages to detect grain variety and other information, and select from literally thousands of combined heating options to cook peak rice. Xiaomiâ€™s sleek white bathroom scale has an LED dial thatâ€™s not visible until you step on the scale; it also uploads your weight to a smartphone app, allowing you to track weight gain or loss over time. â€œChina is set to embrace a consumption boom over the next 10 to 20 years, we see that crystal clear,â€ Liu says. â€œWhat Xiaomi aims to do is to feed these surging demands by introducing products with good quality at a relatively cheap price.â€ The companyâ€™s focus, he adds, is on consumers in Chinaâ€™s second- and third-tier cities, especially those between ages 17 and 35. Clay Shirky, author of the 2015 book, Little Rice: Smartphones, Xiaomi, and the Chinese Dream and one of Xiaomiâ€™s most vocal admirers, is sceptical. â€œItâ€™s not clear that thereâ€™s a business-to-consumer model that works for the so-called Internet of Things,â€ he says. â€œWhat do you want your fitness band to say to your rice cooker? Why does your television need to be in communication with your Segway? No one has gotten that right, not even Amazon.â€ To date, Huami is the most obviously successful device company in which Xiaomi holds a minority stake. Huamiâ€™s Mi is the top-selling fitness band in China, according to Canalys, and No. 2 globally after Fitbit. However, Ding says, supply-chain hiccups hurt Mi band shipments earlier this year and it will take time for Xiaomi to get its other startup partners shipping products reliably. Whatâ€™s more, theyâ€™ve yet to deliver many appealing hardware innovations, according to IDC analyst Jean Xiao. She says Xiaomiâ€™s drone didnâ€™t offer any more features that market leader DJIâ€™s model. â€œThen DJI lowered its price, so it was actually cheaper than Xiaomi.â€ Donâ€™t count Xiaomi out, Liu says. The company isnâ€™t aiming to compete on the high-end with DJI or anyone else. â€œOur primary goal remains to serve the growing middle class in China.â€ â€” Bloomberg Â Â  Â Â  Â Â  Â Â  Â Â  MORE ON MMOTV Most Viewed Now Week Facebook accidentally declares some users dead, including founder Zuckerberg Facebookâ€™s Mark Zuckerberg says fake news didnâ€™t drive election (VIDEO) Sony seeks to patent method for measuring journalists' accuracy The best action cams for winter sports Consumer drone business stumbles, but commercial markets beckon Apple now sells refurbished iPhones Robotic dinosaur replicas stomp in Tokyo hotel (VIDEO) Best smartphones for holiday 2016 Facebookâ€™s Mark Zuckerberg says fake news didnâ€™t drive election (VIDEO) Malaysian gaming content exports soar 75pc to RM80m Most Watched Now Week Reuters Video: Models with Down Syndrome team up with celebrities Reuters Video: Reflection â€˜healthyâ€™ for Democratic party, says Obama 'Beauty and the Beast' first full-length trailer Ah Beng reviews iguanaâ€™s epic escape from snakes (WARNING: EXPLICIT LANGUAGE) Reuters Video: Philippinesâ€™ Duterte says â€˜Long live Trumpâ€™ Reuters Video: Duchess meets movie-star cat, animals go wild Related Articles Xiaomi unveils Starck-designed smartphone and VR headset New-gen Android handsets and smartwatches in store for IFA 2016 Three smartphones with high-end specs priced under US$400 Xiaomi suits up for debut on Appleâ€™s US home turf Digerati50: Making and losing a billion, at 37 Advertisement MMO Instagram Tweets by @themmailonline Tweets by @themmailonline MMOTV News Malaysia World Money Life Showbiz Opinion Sports Eat/Drink Travel Read Tech/Gadgets Drive Gallery Copyright Â© 2016 Malay Mail Online About Us | Contact Us | Policies | Search | Archive | E-Paper | Mobile | ProjekMMO | RecomN - Local Services

Battling for influence â€” Hu Xijin, editor-in-chief, Global Times Review â€” â€˜Payoffâ€™ by Dan Ariely Life & Arts Sections Life & Arts Home House & Home Books Food & Drink Travel Style Arts FT Magazine Most Read US against the world? Trumpâ€™s America and the new global order Milan, Italyâ€™s most business-focused city, looks to rival London Why people shouldnâ€™t snigger at Trumpâ€™s opulent $100m penthouse The $88m student digs: homebuying for children of the super-rich How Qatar is feeling the heat Sign In Subscribe Menu Search Home World US Companies Markets Opinion Work & Careers Life & Arts Financial Times Sign In Subscribe Search the FT Search Close Mobile devices Add to myFT Battery life: Google Pixel XL v iPhone 7 Plus Testing smartphones on their longevity and ability to hold photos, videos and songs Personal Technology Read latest: Yota Devices shifts operations to China Monday, 14 November, 2016 Side by side: the iPhone 7 Plus, left, and the Google Pixel XL Twitter Facebook LinkedIn Whatsapp Print this page Save October 21, 2016 by: Tim Bradshaw Early buyers of electric cars in the 1990s coined a term to describe the gnawing dread that their battery might run out before they got home: â€œrange anxietyâ€. Today, range anxiety is far more ubiquitous due to our pocket supercomputers. Not only are we worried about our smartphoneâ€™s battery lasting the day, but also whether its memory will be sufficient to hold all those photos, videos, songs, apps and software updates. This problem is a moving target. As the resolution of mobile cameras improves, image sizes increase, particularly with 4K video. Apps and games are becoming more sophisticated, consuming more processing power. A lot has to do with users: the more time we spend staring at our screens, the faster the batteries drain. Makers have been slow to compensate for the increasing strain we put on our phones. The latest handsets from Apple and Google go some way to solving it, with more storage â€” on the device and in the cloud â€” and much-improved battery life. Longevity is relevant because both companies are pushing their phones into the most demanding territory yet, by trying to turn them into personal portable concierges. Lookalike hardware I have been testing the iPhone 7 Plus alongside the Google Pixel XL for about a week. (I prefer the more expensive larger phones, but most points in this review also apply to their small-screen siblings.) The Pixel is the latest in a long line of would-be â€œiPhone killersâ€ from Google. I loved last yearâ€™s Nexus 6P but Google argues that the Pixel is different because it had greater involvement in shaping both hardware (which is built by HTC) and software. That approach of tying the two together has been Appleâ€™s playbook for decades, so it is disappointing that the Pixel is not more distinctive. Its rounded black rectangle is different primarily because the fingerprint reader is on the back. It lacks the iPhoneâ€™s camera bump but as a result, the wedge-shaped handset is slightly thicker, though also lighter and shorter than its rival. I asked both phones to â€˜show me photos of campingâ€™. Siri heard me right first time but Assistant showed web search results for â€˜my face has a campaignâ€™ When it comes to software, inspiration seems to be travelling in the opposite direction. A new feature of iOS 10 apes Google Now: swipe sideways from the iPhoneâ€™s homescreen to see live widgets, such as the weather, calendar and suggested apps based on time, place and user habits. In many ways, the devices are evenly matched. Both excel on battery life. Whereas previous iPhones and Android devices often failed to last a full day (I admit to being a heavier user than most), I often went to bed without even hitting the â€œred zoneâ€ of low power on either device. Battery management software in both Android and iOS now kicks in to preserve the life of the phone by cutting background processes to essentials, such as calls and texts. Anyone who shares my daily frustration with battery life would benefit from upgrading. There is one crucial difference in endurance between the two devices, though: the iPhone 7 is waterproof while the Pixel is not. Clouds apart FT on WhatsApp Get the FTâ€™s daily editorâ€™s pick on WhatsApp Where the two devices begin to part ways is in their connected cloud services, which are key to alleviating the pressure on internal memory. Googleâ€™s neat solution to this kind of range anxiety is â€œSmart Storageâ€. If your device is running low on memory, flip a switch in the settings and it will delete older images that have been backed up to the cloud on Google Photos. It is also offering Pixel owners unlimited storage on Google Photos at full resolution â€” including hefty 4K videos. Even if you do not own a Pixel, Google is already slightly more generous with its free cloud storage than Apple. Where iCloud offers only 5GB free, Google allows 15GB â€” but that has to cover Gmail and Drive storage as well as photos. Pricing for extra storage evens out: Apple charges $1 a month for 50GB, Google charges $2 for 100GB. Apple has a 200GB tier for $3 and both offer 1TB for $10 a month. Digital butler All this cloud storage, however, is only useful if you have a good search tool to find your files once uploaded. Pixel is the first phone to feature Google Assistant, a digital butler that is accessed Siri-style by pressing and holding the home button or calling out â€œOK Googleâ€. I found Assistant good but not significantly better than Siri. In one test, I asked both Siri and Assistant to â€œshow me photos of campingâ€ from the large library of images I had previously uploaded to both Apple and Googleâ€™s clouds. Siri heard me right first time and produced about a dozen pictures. Most were of the tent from my most recent camping trip and a few were random outdoorsy photos that were taken nowhere near a campsite. Not terrible but not particularly comprehensive, especially as Iâ€™ve been using iCloud to back up my pictures for years. Wearable technology Personal tech to improve running technique Measuring stride, paces per minute, bounce and foot strike to go faster and limit injuries Assistant first tried to show me web search results for â€œmy face has a campaignâ€. A second attempt at machine-readable elocution was more successful but showed only web search results of camping pics, not my own pictures. After adding the possessive â€œShow me my photos of campingâ€, Google produced many happy camping memories I had uploaded to its Photos service, stretching back more than a decade. These included not just pictures of campsites but fireside suppers and beach walks from the same trips. Bafflingly, however, it did not find the most recent tent photo that Siri did. It is worth noting that Google Photos is also available as a standalone iOS app. It even comes with a â€œfree-up spaceâ€ option that clears all the original photos from your iPhone once they are backed up to Google. The files will be stored at a lower resolution than if you buy a Pixel, though. Verdict Both the iPhone 7 and Googleâ€™s Pixel provide long-overdue ways to mitigate range anxiety. But solving one problem may lead to another kind of nervousness, this time about privacy. Taking full advantage of the Pixelâ€™s cloud back-up and Assistant means going all-in on Google, giving its smartphone constant access to your location, your photos and your most personal information. If that sounds too much to entrust to one company, then combining Appleâ€™s hardware with some of Googleâ€™s software may provide a better balance. Sample the FTâ€™s top stories for a week You select the topic, we deliver the news. By Rehan Hooda 13 Â  Comments 5 reasons why LeEcoâ€™s TV will beat Samsung in India? 5 Â  Comments Researchers find that surface of Mars is so dry that it is uninhabitable 4 Â  Comments Currency ban: An analysis of social media sentiment around Indiaâ€™s latest financial regulation By Nash David 3 Â  Comments Amazon India could kill Netflix with this new Prime Video subscription plan By tech2 News Staff 3 Â  Comments Top Reviews Pixel XL (32GB) Editor rating : 8 Price: 67,000 iPhone 7 Plus (256GB) Editor rating : 8 Price: 92,000 ThinkPad X1 Carbon (Core i5-6300U) Editor rating : 8 Price: 106,000 XPS 13 Core i7 (Z560035HIN9) Editor rating : 8 Price: 133,000 Z2 Plus (4GB RAM/64GB) Editor rating : 7.5 Price: 19,999 You are here: Home > News & Analysis> After irregular storage speeds, Apple iPhone 7 variants show varying levels of network performance #Apple iPhone 7 0 By tech2 News Staff /Â  21 Oct 2016 , 10:16 Similar to last yearâ€™s Apple iPhone 6s, where Appleâ€™s choice of going ahead with Samsung and TSMC chipsets resulted in a difference in performance and battery life, more discoveries about performance irregularities have begun to surface with this yearâ€™s iPhone 7 as well. After GSMArena pointed out how the 32GB version of the iPhone 7 uses a much slower storage module, there is now another report by Cellular Insights that points to varying levels of network reception in places where the network signal could beÂ a bit weak. Apple this year, with its iPhone 7 models used Qualcomm modems on some and Intel modems on othersÂ devices. While the consumer thinks that both in reality should perform identically in the same conditions, testing by Cellular Insights in a report by Apple Insider show irregularities. While both Qualcomm and Intel-based units performed the same in areas with good coverage, in areas with a fainter signal, Qualcomm units outperformed the Intel ones. By how much? Well, that performance gap would be roughly 30 percent. To give better insight (rather making things worse) following tests also included other smartphones for comparison like the iPhone 6s, LG G5, Nexus 5X and the Samsung Galaxy S7 edge. From the report, its clear that Intel-based iPhone 7 got left in the dust while the Galaxy S7 edge was the winner. For now it isnâ€™t clear how much of a difference this has made to users of the iPhone 7 (or whether they have even noticed the reception problem). Moreover, Apple recently pushed out an update that addressed earlier reception issues, and customers donâ€™t seem to be reporting too many problems with reception as well (for now). FIRSTPOST TECH2 FAKING NEWS News & Analysis Reviews Startup Gaming Biztech Auto Videos TechFirstpost most commented Google Allo, WhatsApp, Messenger, Telegram; which is the best messaging app for you? By Rehan Hooda 13 Â  Comments 5 reasons why LeEcoâ€™s TV will beat Samsung in India? 5 Â  Comments Researchers find that surface of Mars is so dry that it is uninhabitable 4 Â  Comments Currency ban: An analysis of social media sentiment around Indiaâ€™s latest financial regulation By Nash David 3 Â  Comments Amazon India could kill Netflix with this new Prime Video subscription plan By tech2 News Staff 3 Â  Comments Top Reviews Pixel XL (32GB) Editor rating : 8 Price: 67,000 iPhone 7 Plus (256GB) Editor rating : 8 Price: 92,000 ThinkPad X1 Carbon (Core i5-6300U) Editor rating : 8 Price: 106,000 XPS 13 Core i7 (Z560035HIN9) Editor rating : 8 Price: 133,000 Z2 Plus (4GB RAM/64GB) Editor rating : 7.5 Price: 19,999 You are here: Home > News & Analysis> Diwali 2016: 7 Best deals on accessories for your brand new iPhone 7 #iPhone 7 0 By tech2 News Staff /Â  21 Oct 2016 , 08:45 So you waited in line for a couple of hours and managed to bag the iPhone 7 or the iPhone 7 Plus. It is time to accessorise the device, and what better time to do it than right now. There are a ton of Diwali deals and offers across e-commerce sites, hereâ€™s a selection of useful and interesting accessories. Safe Cables 4 Units Pack Tired of your iPhone cables twisting and the outer case getting ripped apart near the point of contact? This cord protector is just the thing you need, it strengthens the most stressed points on the cable, and makes sure that you dont have wires hanging out of the cord after long periods of use. There are four cable protectors in each set, so you can protect the cords on all your Apple devices. There are two layers in the protector, an inner one to prevent twists and bends in the cable, and an outer one to prevent wear and tear from friction. Together, the layers prevent the cord from fraying. The 4 units are available for Rs 249, a 50 percent discount from the regular price of Rs 498. EI Black Mobile HolderÂ  The El Black Mobile mount has a flexible body that can be twisted and turned to adjust the position of the phone as per requirement.Â The holder is made out of plastic. The stand has a clip on one end to anchor it, and a holder on the other end where the phone is placed. The clip can be attached to tables, interiors of vehicles or the headrest of a bed to allow using your device in various hands-free ways. This is useful for reducing fatigue, especially for operating the phone while sleeping. The mount is available for Rs 167, which is a steep 83 percent discount from the regular list price of Rs 999. Oeago iPhone 7 Plus CoverÂ  Accentuate the sleek looks of your iPhone 7 Plus with this rugged case fromÂ Oeago. The case slips on to fit the iPhone 7, and has two layers of protection against bumps and scratches. The case provides a rock solid grip as well, although it is a bit on the bulky side. The case has a kickstand that can be used to keep the phone at an angle on a table for all those binge watching sessions or for video conferencing. It also ensures the Apple logo will not be hidden. The case comes in black, andÂ available at 25 percent discount for Rs 1,173. iPhone 7Â Transparent Case If you are one of those Apple users who likes to keep their devices sans a case, but still want to protect the device from bumps and scratches, then this is the perfect case for you. Crafted of see-through Silicone, itÂ has a simple snap on installation. The case is designed for the latest iPhone 7, although the image does not show it. The case is available at a steep 92 percent discount for just Rs 66, as against a regular list price of Rs 799. SanDisk iXpand USB 2.0 16 GB USB OTG Pen Drive The iXpand Flash drive is a great tool to move content to and from your iPhone. The flash drive has two connectors, a lightning connector and a universal serial bus connector. You can easily move data from the iPhone to a laptop or a desktop, without the need to use the cloud or a local Wi-Fi hotspot. To transfer the content on the phone, users will require to download and install the iExpand application. For non iOS devices, the expandable storage works as a regular USB drive. On sale for Rs 3,095, the device is discounted by 31 percent from a regular list price of Rs 4,499. AlcoaÂ Prime 8 Pin Lightning to micro-USB Converter Instead of carrying around a cable for charging, you can travel light by just pocketing this tiny micro USB adapter for the lightning port. Any micro USB cable can then be used to charge this phone with the adapter. Additionally, this allows your iPhone to useÂ Android accessories that use the micro USB slot. The adapter is small enough to fit in a wallet. ItÂ can be used to transfer photos and videos on the iPhone as well, if a lightning cable is not available. Syncing, and backing up the device is also possible. The adapter is available for only Rs 50. Parrot BeBop Drone You can capture amazing images and videos using the Parrot BeBop Drone. The quadcopter has a three axis stabilisation that makes sure that the videos captured are not too jerky. The drone has aÂ 14 megapixel Full HD 1080p camera with a fisheye lens. The lens can record photos and videos in a 180 degree field of view. The drone runs on Linux and sets up its own battery pack. The materials are strong, and there is a shell for indoor flight, and in case something goes wrong, every part of the drone is available for purchase separately, for easy replacement. In case of a collision, the blades stop moving on their own, and there is an emergency landing sequence coded into the drone. There is an in-built GPS for high altitude controls, and an automatic return home function. The drone is available for Rs 65,999, which is 33 percent discount from the regular price of Rs 98,999. The Indian Express Nation World Opinion Entertainment Lifestyle Technology Viral Photos Videos E-Paper Apps RSS Home Compare News Mobile & Tabs Gadgets Science Indian Express Home Home Technology Gadgets Amazon Fire TV streaming devices wonâ€™t be soÂ Amazon-focused Amazon Fire TV streaming devices wonâ€™t be soÂ Amazon-focused Amazon will offer viewers a choice of providers. If a video is available for free through Netflix, for instance, that will be the most prominent option By: AP | New York | Published:October 21, 2016 8:42 am Amazon will offer viewers a choice of providers. If a video is available for free through Netflix, for instance, that will be the most prominent option (Source: AP) Amazonâ€™s own video store will no longer have the starring role on the companyâ€™s Fire TV streaming devices. Software updates coming this year will give movies and TV shows from Netflix, HBO and other competitors equal prominence on the devicesâ€™ home screen. The approach is similar to one Apple took when it refreshed its Apple TV device last year.Â Amazonâ€™s Fire TV has offered solid performance at reasonable prices, but its home screen has been cluttered with Amazon products â€“ whether to rent or buy, or offered at no extra charge through Amazonâ€™s $99-a-year Prime program. Thatâ€™s made it tough to find video from competing providers without turning to a voice-search feature that, until recently, excluded Netflix. For the most part, finding video typically required opening a serviceâ€™s app first. Now, competing services will be offered space on the home screen. Netflix, for instance, could choose to highlight its original series â€œStranger Thingsâ€ alongside personalized recommendations. Netflix could also include a short video trailer that plays on the home screen. And while Amazon has long had a watch list for viewers to keep track of what they want to watch, choosing a title has directed the viewer back to Amazonâ€™s store. Now, Amazon will offer viewers a choice of providers. If a video is available for free through Netflix, for instance, that will be the most prominent option, even if Amazonâ€™s own store is selling the same title. The development comes as leading video services make major investments in original shows, making it difficult for any single service to fulfill all of a viewerâ€™s needs. An Amazon-centric approach penalizes viewers looking for not just Amazonâ€™s â€œTransparentâ€ but also Netflixâ€™s â€œLuke Cageâ€ and Huluâ€™s â€œThe Mindy Project.â€ J&K Schools: Amid Shutdown, Restrictions, Board ExaminationsÂ Begin Ghazipur: PM Modi Flags Off Shabd BhediÂ Express Ghazipur: PM Modi Promises To Open Files Of PatelÂ Committee This Is How People Celebrate Guru NanakÂ Jayanti Nation Celebrates Guru NanakÂ Jayanti Demonetisation: Brinda Karat Calls PM Modiâ€™s Speech â€˜Dramaâ€™ Vizag Police Nabs Prisoners Escaped From Warangal CentralÂ Jail Demonetisation Will Affect Fashion Industry Only In Short Run, Feels DesignerÂ Sabyasachi New Zealand: Two Killed In 7.8 MagnitudeÂ Earthquake Demonetisation: Banking Correspondents Can Withdraw Cash Multiple Times, Says ShaktikantaÂ Das PM Modi Claims Demonetisation Has Left Corrupts With â€˜NoÂ Optionâ€™ Golfer Aditi Ashok becomes first Indian Woman to lift European TourÂ Event PM Modi at KLE: Win gold medals for India in 2020Â Olympics Idea Exchange With UjjalÂ Dosanjh India Manage A Draw After Anxious DayÂ 5 Also Read:Â Amazon announces new music streaming service to challenge Apple and Spotify The refreshed Fire TV Stick, which begins shipping Thursday for $40, will get the free software update first, followed by the standard $100 Fire TV device released last year. Both will get the updates by the end of the year. Amazon says older devices will get the updates, too, but no timetable was given. Jones , USA TODAY 7:48 p.m. EDT October 20, 2016 7.1k Shares 'Watch the Throne' fall? Â (Photo: Christopher Polk, Getty Images For BET) Kanye West aired a littleÂ Family BusinessÂ during his Saint Pablo tour stop in Seattle Wednesday. While onstage, the rapper shared that he and his "big brother"Â Jay Z will not collaborate on a follow-up to their platinum-selling collaborative album,Â Watch the Throne. The reason?Â "TIDAL/Apple bull----." West says the ongoing tension between the competing streaming services is also why his verse on Pop StyleÂ didn't makeÂ the studio version of Drake's ViewsÂ album,Â which was released exclusively on Apple.Â "It will never be aÂ Watch The Throne 2," heÂ said. "You know why? Because thatâ€™s the reason why I wasnâ€™t on the song. I wasnâ€™t on the song 'cause of Hov. 'Cause itâ€™s this TIDAL/Apple bull----." And those politics seem to have gotten personal with West revealing thatÂ North, his 3-year-old daughter with Kim Kardashian,Â and Blue Ivy, Jay Z's 4-year-old daughterÂ with BeyoncÃ©, haven't even had a playdate. "IÂ canâ€™t take this (expletive), bro!" West said.Â "Our kids ain'tÂ never even played together." And if that wasn't enough to have fans say Mercy,Â West added that he and JayÂ Z haven't seen each otherÂ since Kim Kardashian's traumaticÂ robberyÂ experience in Paris. "Don't call me after the robbery and say, 'How you feelin'?'" heÂ said. "You wanna know how I'm feelin'? Come by the house. Bring the kids by the house. Like we brothers, let's sit down." LeEco enters US consumer tech market | Bangkok Post: tech Top sections News Business Video Photos Opinion Lifestyle Auto Jobs Property Travel Learning More TECHNOLOGY Log in Sign up Web search MENU Search Switch Archive Today's paper DIGITAL VERSION SIGN IN About E-Newspaper Subscribe Report problem Free Trial HOME DELIVERY Technology Homepage World updates Local news Reviews Apps Mobile & tablets Computers Gadgets Buy & sell Tech > World Updates LeEco enters US consumer tech market 21 Oct 2016 at 04:00 1,022 viewed0 comments NEWSPAPER SECTION: BUSINESS | WRITER: ASSOCIATED PRESS A LeEco uMax 85 television is displayed at an event in San Francisco on Wednesday.â€‰(AP photo) - + SAN FRANCISCO: Most US consumers haven't heard of LeEco, but the Chinese technology company is setting out to become a household name with smartphones and flat-screen TVs that undercut the prices of Apple, Google, Samsung and other industry stalwarts. LeEco heralded its entrance into the US market during a Wednesday showcase in San Francisco, where the company unveiled a sleek smartphone called the LePro 3 that will sell for $400 and an internet-connected TV with a seven-foot screen priced at $5,000. LeEco positions the LePro 3 as an alternative to Apple Inc's latest iPhone and Google's Pixel phone, whose prices both start at $650. The company is promising its giant TV, called the UMax 85, will be as good or better than other high-end home entertainment systems that cost $8,000. Both the phone and TV will go on sale Nov 2 in LeEco's online store, LeWeb.com. The company is also selling a smaller smartphone and smaller TVs with screens ranging from 43 inches to 65 inches. Besides the phones and TVs, LeEco also is coming to the US with a virtual-reality headset, a high-tech bicycle and an electric car in a challenge to Tesla Motors Inc. The company wants to bundle the devices with other services, including an online video package of shows and movies that ties into its origins as the "Netflix of China.'' LeEco, which stands for "Happy Ecosystem,'' is branching out to challenge technology leaders who have been able to demand a premium for their products partly because they have been pleasing US consumers for years. "America is the most important global market for us,'' LeEco CEO Jia Yueting said through a translator during a presentation. "Once we get the hearts and minds of US users, we can move on to the hearts and minds of global users.'' Innovation in the US has hit a "bottleneck,'' making it an optimal time for LeEco to enter the market, Jia said in an interview with the Associated Press that was also translated. He envisions creating a platform that enables consumers to hopscotch from LeEco TVs to phones to cars to watch its video service and use other applications that that company plans to introduce. "The company is using the devices as Trojan horses, to deliver its digital services,'' said Gartner Inc analyst Werner Goertz. "This is a general trend in the industry, and LeEco is a prime example of how companies are subsidising hardware with ulterior motives.'' "Google is similarly selling its new Pixel phone in an effort to drive more traffic to its search engine and other service,'' he noted, though that device "is being sold at a premium price.'' Amazon.com Inc's Echo, an internet-connected speaker that understands and responds to spoken language, also is designed to get boost sales at the company's e-commerce site. The expectations for LeEco are modest. Research firm Strategy Analytics Inc projects that LeEco will sell about 25 million smartphones worldwide this year. By comparison, Apple had sold 214 million iPhones in the past year ending in June. Tech companies like Snapchat and Skypeâ€™s owner Microsoft are failing to adopt basic privacy protections on their instant messaging services, putting usersâ€™ human rights at risk, Amnesty International said today. The organizationâ€™s new â€˜Message Privacy Rankingâ€™ assesses the 11 companies with the most popular messaging apps on the way they use encryption to protect usersâ€™ privacy and freedom of expression across their messaging apps. â€œIf you think instant messaging services are private, you are in for a big surprise. The reality is that our communications are under constant threat from cybercriminals and spying by state authorities. Young people, the most prolific sharers of personal details and photos over apps like Snapchat, are especially at risk,â€ said Sherif Elsayed-Ali, Head of Amnesty Internationalâ€™s Technology and Human Rights Team. Amnesty International has highlighted end-to end encryption, a way of scrambling data so that only the sender and recipient can see it, as a minimum requirement for technology companies to ensure that private information in messaging apps stays private. The companies that ranked lowest on the scorecard do not have adequate levels of encryption in place on their messaging apps. â€œIt is up to tech firms to respond to well-known threats to their usersâ€™ privacy and freedom of expression, yet many companies are falling at the first hurdle by failing to provide an adequate level of encryption. Millions of people are using messaging apps that deny them even the most basic privacy protection,â€ said Sherif Elsayed-Ali. Amnesty Internationalâ€™s â€˜Message Privacy Rankingâ€™ ranks technology companies on a scale of one to 100 based on how well they do five things: Â· Recognize online threats to their usersâ€™ privacy and freedom of expression Â· Apply end-to-end encryption as a default Â· Make users aware of threats to their rights, and the level of encryption in place Â· Disclose details of government requests to the company for user data, and how they respond Â· Publish technical details of their encryption systems Tencent, Blackberry and Snapchat score less than 30/100 Chinese firm Tencent came bottom, scoring zero out of 100, ranked as the company taking least action on messaging privacy, and the least transparent. It was followed by Blackberry and Snapchat scoring 20 and 26 respectively. Despite Microsoftâ€™s strong policy commitment to human rights, it is still using a weak form of encryption on Skype, scoring 40 and leaving it four places from the bottom. None of these companies provide end-to-end encryption of their usersâ€™ communications. Snapchat, a US-based company used by more than 100 million people every day, also scored badly. Although it has a strong policy commitment towards privacy, in practice it does not do enough to protect its usersâ€™ privacy. It does not deploy end-to-end encryption, for example, and is not transparent in informing users about the threats to their human rights or its use of encryption. Facebook, Apple lead the way No company provides watertight privacy, but Facebook, whose apps Facebook Messenger and WhatsApp together have 2 billion users, has the highest score with 73 out of 100. Facebook is doing the most out of the 11 companies assessed to use encryption to respond to human rights threats, and is most transparent about the action itâ€™s taking. However, despite including end-to-end encryption as an option with its new â€œsecret conversationâ€ feature, Facebook Messengerâ€™s default mode uses a weaker form of encryption, which means Facebook has access to all the data. WhatsApp uses end-to-end encryption by default and notably provides clear information to users about encryption within the app. Apple scored 67 out of 100, providing full end-to-end encryption in all communications on its iMessage and Facetime apps. But Apple needs to do more to make users aware that SMS messages are less secure than iMessages. The company should also adopt a more open encryption protocol that allows for full independent verification. End-to-end encryption: a basic protection few firms provide Instant messaging services like WhatsApp, Skype and Viber are used by hundreds of millions of people every day. This includes human rights activists, opposition politicians and journalists living in countries where their work could put them in grave danger. With large data breaches occurring all too frequently and governmentsâ€™ mass surveillance operations unabated, the strongest encryption as well as transparency about who has access to message data, is key to protecting them. Yet only three firms, Apple, Line and Viber scored full marks for providing end-to-end encryption by default on all their messaging apps. â€œMost technology companies are simply not up to standard when it comes to protecting their usersâ€™ privacy. Activists around the world rely on encryption to protect themselves from spying by authorities, and it is unacceptable for technology companies to expose them to danger by failing to adequately respond to the human rights risks,â€ said Sherif Elsayed-Ali. â€œThe future of privacy and free speech online depends to a very large extent on whether tech companies provide services that protect our communications, or serve them up on a plate for prying eyes.â€ Amnesty International is calling on companies to apply end-to-end encryption to messaging apps as a default. This would help protect the rights of everyday people, as well as peaceful activists and persecuted minorities all over the world by enabling them to exercise their freedom of speech. It is also calling on technology companies to publish full details of the policies and practices they have in place to meet their responsibility to respect the rights to privacy and freedom of expression. ends Content Sourced from scoop.co.nz Original url Â Print This Post Tweet Â  Â  Blogroll China Economic Scan Compare house prices Deposit Rates Direct Broking â€“ NZX & ASX Trading & Prices Findata â€“ Market Data Good Returns Herald Business Interest.co.nz â€“ Interest Rates News & Views National Business Review Property Talk Sharechat Stuff Business Value Cruncher â€“ NZX Latest Business news DCC Blocks 2017 Petroleum Offer Theresa Gattung Venture Capital fund Tower estimates quake could trim profit by up to $7.2 mln MYOB awarded Service Provider of the Year Antipodes Gold Reverse Takeover Update Hamiltonâ€™s outlying villages see boost in house hunters New World Kaikoura re-opens NZ dollar little changed below 71 US cents as greenback Unique chance to develop consented lifestyle land in Twizel Candidates for Fonterra Board of Directorsâ€™ Election Go Green Expo a breeding ground for pseudoscience Update to Wellington roads Wellington highways closed due to surface flooding When strangers call bearing investment gifts: hang up Fonterra chooses Epson projectors for dynamic edge blending Text Links Recent Comments Lan: Unbelievable that a WEST AUSTR... jackp: Murray, when Key is involved t... Features Reviews Phones Android iPhone Windows Phone Apps Computers Laptops Lenovo Tablets Windows Tutorials Events More Audio Crowfunding Design/Concepts Gadgets Gaming General Photo/Video Web Ubergizmo in French Ubergizmo in German Ubergizmo in Italian Ubergizmo in Spanish Kanye West Blames Apple Music/Tidal Rivalry For Killing Projects By Tyler Lee on 10/20/2016 18:39 PST While there are plenty of music streaming services out there today that could be considered competition for Apple Music, the Cupertino companyâ€™s music streaming service seems to be more closely associated with the likes of Tidal. Now competition is generally considered healthy, which is why regulatory companies tend to frown upon monopolies. However if there is someone who doesnâ€™t appreciate the Apple Music/Tidal rivalry, it would be none other than artist Kanye West. Speaking during his Saint Pablo tour, West revealed that the rivalry could have potentially killed off some projects. West named one song in particular â€œPop Styleâ€ in which the original song by Drake featured both him and Jay-Z, but apparently that version did not make it onto Drakeâ€™s VIEWS album due to the rivalry between Apple Music and Tidal. According to West, â€œYâ€™all didnâ€™t get, what yâ€™all were supposed to get with me and Drake on this song because of some Tidal/Apple bullshit. Every time I perform this song I think about this shit. I think about the politics. I think about how hard I go for music, for art, for yâ€™all.â€ He also adds that a second â€œWatch The Throneâ€ album will not be possible due to the rivalry as well. â€œIt will never be a Watch The Throne 2. You know why? Because thatâ€™s the reason why I wasnâ€™t on the song. I wasnâ€™t on the song cause of Hov. Cause itâ€™s this TIDAL/Apple bullshit. And this shit be getting me tight every time I perform this muthafucka.â€ Drakeâ€™s affiliation with Apple is well-documented, with his (in)famous â€œHotline Blingâ€ video having been funded by Apple themselves. West himself has proven to be more of a Tidal fan and his album, The Life of Pablo, was initially exclusive to Tidal before it was eventually released onto both Spotify and Apple Music. Filed in Apple >Audio. Read more about apple music, Music and tidal. Related Articles 2016-11-11 Spotifyâ€™s Desktop App Found Writing Huge Amounts Of Data Onto Hard Drives 2016-11-10 Spotify Launches â€˜Drawn & Recordedâ€™, An Original Animated Series 2016-11-02 MacBook Pro Touch Bar Support For Logic Pro X Coming Next Year 2016-11-01 Apple Rumored To Be Considering 20% Decrease In Apple Music Price 2016-10-31 Pirated CDs Are Making Their Way Into Reputable Online Stores 2016-09-20 Music Streaming Is Helping Boost The Music Industryâ€™s Revenue 2016-09-15 Apple Denies Rumors That They Are Acquiring Tidal 2016-07-01 Apple Rumored To Be Considering Tidal Acquisition 2016-03-16 Jay-Z Pulls More Albums Off Non-Tidal Music Streaming Services Thief Steals Galaxy Note 7, It Ends Up Exploding Snapchat Introduces New AR â€˜World Lensesâ€™ Feature The Sega Genesis Will Be Going Back Into Production AT&T DirecTV Now Streaming Service Might Offer Free Apple TVs New HTC Bolt Rendering Leaked In Black Uncourage Keychain Helps Prevent Losing The iPhone 7â€™s 3.5mm Adapter User Comments Please enable JavaScript to view the comments
RecomN - Local Services|Â About Us|Â E-Paper|Â Search|Â MOBILE KLIK UNTUK PROJEKMMO ç‚¹å‡»Mä¸­æ–‡ç½‘ Facebook Twitter RSS Last updated Tuesday, November 15, 2016 8:20 am GMT+8 Kuala Lumpur Â°C, MMOTV News Malaysia World Money Life Showbiz Opinion Sports Eat/Drink Travel Read Tech/Gadgets Drive Gallery Tech/Gadgets The new Apple Watch is still king of the smartwatches (VIDEO) By Erna Mahyuni Friday October 21, 2016 08:31 AM GMT+8 ICYMI The Edit: Frida Kahlo painting, unseen for 60 years, surfaces for sale Rooney out of Spain game, Henderson to captain England The Edit: Supermoon wows stargazers tonight Sweden starts grilling of Assange at Ecuador embassy Advertisement More stories Â Â  Â Â  Â Â  Â Â  Â Â  Tools Increase Text Decrease Text Reset Text Print Article The Apple Watch series 2 has an updated processor, GPS as well as water-resistance. â€” Pic by Erna MahyuniKUALA LUMPUR, Oct 21 â€” The Apple Watch series 2 makes its official debut in Malaysia today. If you're wondering whether it's worth picking up, I'd say yes â€” with a few caveats. If you don't have an iPhone, then, sorry, the Apple Watch is not for you. For iPhone users, the new series 2 will appeal most to those who have tried or considered a fitness band, but found them lacking. Looks do matter While other watches such as the Huawei Watch or Moto 360 have tried to ape the design of traditional watches, the new Apple Watch maintains the large, squarish watch case and it unabashedly stands out as a digital device. This time, however, the Watch adds a ceramic case as an option, besides stainless steel and aluminium. Why ceramic? Apple's choice is actually pretty current in the world of watches; ceramic watches being prized for their resistance to scratches. Non-ceramic case Watches do use zirconia ceramic at the back - it's non-conductive and unlike metal, will not interfere with the wireless charger used to recharge the watch's battery. Even if you choose the cheapest aluminium case, it's easy enough to dress up the watch by selecting one of the many bands available. It is super simple to replace the Watch's bands. Merely depress a latch on the case and you can slide a strap out of the requisite slot, to fit in a new one. Of course, some might complain about the proprietary design that doesn't make buying an ordinary watch strap an option. Still, Apple provides enough colour options and materials â€” nylon, stainless steel, fluoroelastomer (Apple's custom polymer sport band material) â€” that you'd be have quite a few choices. There are also third-party straps on the market, though they are harder to come by in Malaysia. This reviewer's particular favourite is the classy Milanese Loop band. With its chain link finish and magnetic clasp, it is easily adjustable to any wrist size. The black stainless steel case with the black Milanese Loop band variant is probably the best looking in the bunch; only pity is that Apple only offers its ceramic case in white. A black ceramic case would probably sell pretty well judging by how popular the Jet Black iPhones are right now. A better battery Apple has tweaked the new Watch to have a better battery, after criticism over the last version's unimpressive battery life. In testing, I found the watch to last about two days for ordinary usage (no workout logging) but on workout days, would need charging after about a day's usage. The continued Bluetooth connection to your smartphone will not take much of a toll on the Watch but will sap your iPhone. My recommendation? Don't forget to turn off the Bluetooth on your iPhone at night but you can still set your phone in Nightstand mode, placing it on its side and on the charger. You can even set an Alarm on the Watch, no iPhone needed. Even with notifications and playing a few Apple Watch-compatible games, I found the Apple Watch's battery would last me through the day. A marathon runner, however, might find the battery draining faster with GPS and the heart rate monitor enabled. You can disable the latter as well as the fitness tracker to save battery on days they're not being used. Choosing the new series 2 means more strap options at your nearest Apple store. Your swimming companion What will appeal to regular swimmers is the Apple Watch's waterproofing. While it's not made for activities that require deep immersion (scuba diving) or heavier water activity (jet skis), for swimming in the pool, the Apple Watch works just fine. It now has a special lock function that will auto-lock the Watch when it detects water and to unlock it, all you need to is turn the digital crown on the right side of Watch until the screen indicator says your watch is unlocked. The special unlocking function also dispels water from the Watch's speakers -- very neat. Wearing it in the shower, as I've tried, is also pretty convenient. You can still glance at the time, when you turn the watch face towards you, but you can't use the Watch to answer calls or access other functions, thanks to the auto-lock mechanism. Do note that you shouldn't do this if you're using a leather or steel strap: stick to showering with the sports band strap with the Watch instead. A Zen-like experience A new app on the Watch might win my personal "least annoying/most useful default app ever" award. I'm talking about the Breathe app. The Breathe app is the equivalent of a Meditation 101 app; at certain intervals, it will exhort you to take a short break to just breathe â€” showing an animation as well as vibrating on your wrist as you inhale and exhale. You can even customise how long the sessions last, as well as how often you get the reminder to use the app. It's a nice way to help those who find themselves stressed on a regular basis find time to just, as the app says, breathe. Sure, it sounds super hippie and a little twee, but just taking a few deep breaths to calm yourself can be a great help. The screen is twice as bright now, with a 1,000 nit rating: bright enough to be easily viewable outside or indoors. Minor niggles While the Workout app works fine when tracking ordinary workouts such as running or swimming, it's not quite as smart at tracking workouts on the "Other" spectrum. Despite doing heavy work clearing brush and felling overgrown foliage in my backyard, the watch insisted I had only burned 160 calories all day. My aching arms and back would probably disagree. The watch did freeze on me a couple of times during the week I was testing it but a simple reboot sorted it out. What I was not quite crazy about was the learning curve at trying to navigate the Home screen and switching through apps; it was a lot less intuitive than I'd like â€” a tweak of the Apple Watch app might make it easier for future new users of the Watch. What is certain, though is that this is a very good, fitness-centric upgrade of the Apple Watch series. Overall, the Apple Watch still offers a far more fun and seamless experience when compared to its Android Wear rivals and is much better looking than any of the dedicated fitness bands out there. When it comes to a smartwatch that works well for both work and play, the Apple Watch still does it better. For the more budget-conscious, the original Apple Watch is a much cheaper option at RM1,199 but the older processor is slower and it does not have GPS or waterproofing, with only the aluminium case with sports band option available on the online store. You might, however, find the older variants selling on discount at local Apple distributors if you're lucky. To view the available models, visit the official online Apple Store. Pricing is as follows: Apple Watch Series 1 (Aluminium case only) Sport Band 38mm: RM1,199 Sport Band 42mm: RM1,299 Apple Watch Series 2 Aluminium case: Sport Band/Woven Nylon 38mm: RM1,649 Sport Band/Woven Nylon 42mm: RM1,749 Stainless Steel case: Sport Band/Woven Nylon 38mm: RM2,499 Sport Band/Woven Nylon 42mm: RM2,749 Saddle Brown Classic Buckle 38mm: RM2,999 Saddle Brown Classic Buckle 42mm: RM3,249 Midnight Blue Modern Buckle 38mm: RM3,499 Midnight Blue Leather Loop 42mm: RM3,249 Milanese Loop 38mm: RM2,999 Milanese Loop 42mm: RM3,249 Link Bracelet 38mm: RM4,299 Link Bracelet 42mm: RM4,549 Black Stainless Steel case: Black Milanese Loop 38mm: RM3,249 Black Milanese Loop 42mm: RM3,449 Black Link Bracelet 38mm: RM4,799 Black Link Bracelet 42mm: RM5,049 Apple Watch Nike+ (Series 2) with Aluminium case: Nike Sport Band 38mm: RM1,649 Nike Sport Band 42mm: RM1,749 Apple Watch Edition (Series 2) with Ceramic case: Sport Band 38mm: RM5,699 Sport Band 42mm: RM5,949 The Apple Watch series 2 and series 1 should be available on the official webstore soon, but it should already be purchaseable at your nearest official Apple distributor. The exclusive Hermes edition, however, will not be purchaseable on the online store but you can instead look for it at select locations listed on this page. Features Reviews Phones Android iPhone Windows Phone Apps Computers Laptops Lenovo Tablets Windows Tutorials Events More Audio Crowfunding Design/Concepts Gadgets Gaming General Photo/Video Web Ubergizmo in French Ubergizmo in German Ubergizmo in Italian Ubergizmo in Spanish iPhone 7 With Qualcomm Modems Have Seemingly Better Reception By Tyler Lee on 10/20/2016 18:36 PST With the new iPhone 7 and 7 Plus, Apple made some changes under the hood which saw the company turn to the use of both Qualcomm and Intel modems for some models of the device. Prior to this, Apple had pretty much used Qualcommâ€™s modems exclusively. When it was discovered that Intelâ€™s modems are being used, we also wondered how this might impact performance. Turns out there is some difference. According to some tests that have been conducted, it was discovered that Qualcommâ€™s modems appear to have better reception in places where the signal is fainter. This means that if youâ€™re inside a building or underground, the tests seem to suggest that the Qualcomm model will provide you with better service than the Intel model. The disparity in performance was not just limited to the iPhone 7. Cellular Insights, who performed the test, brought in other phones as comparisons which included the iPhone 6s, LG G5, Google Nexus 5X, and Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge. It seems that the Intel iPhone 7 got left in the dust while the Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge proved to be the clear winner. Now whether or not this will affect your daily usage remains to be seen. So far there doesnâ€™t appear to be too many complaints regarding reception (there were issues with reception but those were addressed with software fixes), meaning that maybe in real-world usage the disparity canâ€™t be felt as much. It also reminds us of the time the iPhone 6s was discovered to have chipsets made by Samsung and TSMC, with the latter proving to have better battery life than the former, although like we said then, those were merely tests and real-world usage is probably what really matters. But according to CNet, Mr. Cue insisted Apple isnâ€™t trying to go toe-to-toe with companies like Netflix with original programming. â€œYouâ€™re not seeing a huge number of them,â€ he said about Apple original shows. â€œThe real opportunity for us is to make it easier to get access to all this content.â€ Apple TV Apple has been trying to launch some kind of streaming video service for years, with leaks coming from a variety of industry sources. Many (including me) have speculated that Apple might turn to developing its own shows as way of establishing itself in the market, but Mr. Cueâ€™s comments suggest there are limits to what Apple is willing to do on that front. Mr. Cue was on stage with HBO chairman and CEO Richard Plepler. Sections Nightly News MSNBC Meet the Press Dateline Today.com Sun logo Today Search Search Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share on Google Plus Email page link Secondary Navigation Sections U.S. World Local Politics Investigations Health Tech Science Pop Culture Lifestyle Business Weather Sports Latino Asian America NBCBLK NBC OUT Top Ongoing Hot Cars and Kids ISIS UnCovered TV Nightly News Meet The Press Dateline Today Featured NBC News VR College Game Plan Data Points Making a Difference Long Story Short 101 Show Me Flashback 30 Seconds to Know Debunker Multimedia Video Photo More From NBC Sports CNBC MSNBC.com NBC.com Breakingnews.com NBC Learn Re/Code Peacock Productions Next Steps for Vets Parent Toolkit NBC News works best with JavaScript turned on Feedback advertisement advertisement Tech Apple Gadgets Internet Security Innovation Mobile Tech Oct 20 2016, 8:20 pm ET Apple Goes After Phony Fire-Starting Products on Amazon by Alyssa Newcomb Share Share Tweet Share Email Print Comment advertisement It's not just Samsung products that are overheating â€” Apple now has a problem, but with counterfeits. The iPhone maker said it has been buying phony accessories on Amazon bearing the Apple name and found that a whopping 90 percent of those are counterfeit. A customer reviews faulty product after it malfunctions Jack Percher Even more troubling, Apple said, the phony products "pose an immediate threat to consumer safety," because they haven't been put through the rigorous industry standard testing Apple uses. In a review posted Dec. 24, a customer shared a photo of a charred charger, writing that "after just a few hours of use on the every first day, the charger literally caught on fire." Related: First U.S. Suit Filed Over Exploding Samsung Galaxy Note 7 Smartphones With the safety of customers and the protection of its reputation in mind, Apple filed a lawsuit Monday in U.S. District Court in San Francisco against Mobile Star L.L.C., the company selling many of the products Apple bought on Amazon. "Mobile Star has been deceiving Apple customers and putting their safety at risk by selling counterfeit power adapters. They have ignored our repeated requests, so we are taking legal action to get them to stop," Josh Rosenstock, a spokesman for Apple, told NBC News. It's not always easy to tell whether what you're buying is the real deal. An example listed in the lawsuit shows how customers could easily believe they were buying products from Apple when they weren't. The listing says the product's being sold by Apple â€” but the fine print notes that it ships from one of Amazon's fulfillment centers. A customer compares two iPhones at an Apple Store in Chicago last month. AP Amazon identified Mobile Star as the supplier, according to the lawsuit, and turned over the additional inventory of Apple products that the company bought from Mobile Star. Apple said it determined that the majority were fake. Mobile Star didn't immediately respond to NBC News' request for an interview. Amazon wasn't named as a party in the lawsuit. Aaron Toso, a spokesman for Amazon, told NBC News that the retailer "has zero tolerance for the sale of counterfeits on our site." "We work closely with manufacturers and brands, and pursue wrongdoers aggressively," Toso said. For Apple, the problem of counterfeits may be a game of whack-a-mole. The company said in the lawsuit that "each month, Apple identifies and reports many thousands of listings for counterfeit and infringing Apple products to Amazon.com under its notice and takedown procedures." Alyssa Newcomb Twitter Email Topics Apple, Consumer First Published Oct 20 2016, 7:12 pm ET Next Story Apple's New Emojis Include a Creepy Clown and...
